top_comment.text:
Gah, I hate statistics. This is not credible information, even if the 
sample size was 100,000 people, you are still only getting information from 
such a small representation of the population. This information could be 
correct, or totally bollocks, with most statistics there is never a way to 
tell the difference.﻿
top_comment.author: showmemoviesnow

comments.text:
+showmemoviesnow I have no reason to believe otherwise. My first reaction 
to it was what is the wording of the question being asked? Are participants 
made aware of what binge drinking is, or are they just asked something like 
"How often do you binge drink?".
comments.author: ChiefWardo

comments.text:
A agree with most of what you just said, but do you really believe these 
graphs are even close to being accurate?
comments.author: showmemoviesnow

comments.text:
I think your opinion of statistics is unsophisticated. No one is claiming 
100% accuracy in figures when samples are being generalised to populations. 
What we can do is, based on the size of our sample, have levels of 
confidence in our accuracy. For instance, Ana saying that Vietnamese women 
outdrink Vietnamese men because of a 1 percentage point difference is 
highly problematic, because error margins would probably be larger than 1%. 
Another thing is that these are only descriptive statistics (not 
inferential), and the question is therefore less about SIZE as it is about 
sample representation and survey methodology.
comments.author: ChiefWardo

top_comment.text:
This is a super interesting study. I'm Irish, and have a few things to say. 
This is a super cultural thing. I mean 6 drinks in Ireland is not 
considered anywhere near a binge. It's not even close. I was in the pub 
lastnight with my Grandfather, Aunt, Her Partner, The Publican & His wife, 
 a couple I know from Dublin and another guy. We each ordered drinks in the 
round, over 4 hours everyone from my Granddad to me had over 10 drinks. And 
that pub was full. I wouldn't do it every week, I mean I could go months 
and just not bother going to the pub (public house), but the scary point to 
make hear isn't that 10 drinks in my local pub isn't considered excessive, 
when I tell my friends (22-26 years old) I was out for drinking, the fact I 
didn't go out to a night club or disco-bar means it doesn't even count as 
drinking. So when I hear that Cenk considers 6 to be alot, man I gotta 
think- is the super-lib approach the Irish take to drinking seriously 
affecting the health of the entire nation?

Also, on the women stats in Ireland. I'm calling Bullshit straight outta 
the gate on that one. Every woman I see in the shop has like 2/3 bottles of 
wine in their trolley. That's just the older ones, girls in college over 
hear drink phenomenally larger amounts of alcohol than their contemporary 
males. I think it's again a hugely cultural thing, like over here in 
Ireland when a guy can afford to go out and drink every weekend, especially 
in rural Ireland, it's worn as a badge of honour of sorts. Whereas there is 
despite our super-lib approach, a stigma attached to women over a certain 
age being seen to be drinking, either at home or in public, without an 
"occasion to do so." 

I just find 56% such an amazingly high number, I wonder if you measured 
relative to each nations average consumption per drinker, and then measure 
the number of people drinking in excessive of the median, would you get a 
much different number? The only conclusion I can come to is that 
culturally, 6 drinks in one sitting (taking the average visit to the pub to 
be about 4-5 hours, it's 1.5, there or about, and hour) in Ireland, isn't 
considered outrageously much by anyone in all honesty. 

Sorry about the long-winded post, I just think this is an unreal number, 
but still when I think about it, it doesn't even come close to surprising 
me. Our approach to drinking in this country is so laid back, it's actually 
a bit scary in context. ﻿
top_comment.author: ET Cor

comments.text:
Even more substantial than the respondents feeling pressured to answer a 
certain way, I genuinely feel, given first hand experience, that the 
figures wouldn't be a million miles off, however, I'd imagine people have 
compensated and generalised on an average over the year... November/January 
in Ireland very few people drink, November many stop for religious reasons 
and January for financial reasons :P I think the scary point here is that 
the respondents would over the course of a year and on average certainly 
consume more than 6/sitting, but I find it hard to believe that it would be 
every single week...
comments.author: ET Cor

comments.text:
+Drannon Moore  Your comment started out so poorly, you really shocked me.  
I agree that stats are b.s. so it would be best discuss the implications 
and how the government is using this to manipulate us.  That said, you 
missed an important word that I used.  Men.  So we are back to my refined 
answer of 1 in 7.7 men binge drink.  I did inflate the totals in the first 
post but my stats were given so that you could interpret them accurately 
(says the politician).  No harm, no foul.

    My point stands.  Disregarding stats, there are people driving drunk, 
right now, and that is a hazard.  Such a dangerous chemical should not be 
consumed and celebrated the way alcohol is.  Imagine a billboard promoting 
meth.  That is how I feel about alcohol.  It can cause horrible diseases 
but it also dumbs us down, which is a different kind of disease.
comments.author: My real name is I AM

comments.text:
+My real name is I AM  I'm curious as to how you done your math exactly. I 
hate to be the bearer of bad news, but your calculations are off son. 
This probably happened because you didn't take into consideration all the 
aspects of the situation. To accurately estimate how many binge drinkers 
are in America, there are several things you have to remember... 1. How 
many people are in America, 2. How many Americans are adults, 3. How many 
Americans drink, 4. How many Americans are men (and how many are women), 
ect. (See paragraph 3)

I got all of my statistics from the United States Census Bureau, The 
National Institute of Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism, and this video. Before 
I go any further I want to make a valid point, ALL STATISTICS ARE BULLSHIT! 
Period! It doesn't matter whether it's the Young Turks, the US 
government, The Statistics that I am about to use, ect, they are all 
bullshit. How do I know this? Let me answer that with a question... Did any 
men in black suits pull up to your door and ask if you were a binge 
drinker??? No?? Then how do they know the percentage of ALL Americans that 
are binge drinkers if they didn't question ALL Americans??? Truth is, ALL 
statistics are based on so many people (like 70,000 or so) then they place 
those statistics across the whole country. So if they happened to test 
these questions in an area with high alcoholism rates, it may appear that 
many Americans are binge drinkers, when not near as many Americans drink as 
what is concluded in the results. Some statistics may be more accurate than 
other, but until they poll EVERY SINGLE PERSON the results are ALWAYS going 
to be BULLSHIT. So although the statistics I'm about to use are not 
completely accurate, they are the best we have, so here you go.

There are 311,116,000 people in the United States according to the census 
bureau. 74,187,000 people are under 17; 193,642,000 people are between ages 
18 to 64; and 43,287,000 people are 65 and older. That leaves with 
236,929,000 people over the age of 18. 114,448,000 of these are male, 
122,482,000 are female (48.3% male, 51.69% female) . The NIAAA concluded 
that 71% of people 18 and older reported that they drank in the past year; 
56.3% reported that they drank in the past month. Cenk said that anyone who 
has drank any alcohol in the past year qualifies as a drinker, therefore 
71% of everyone 18 and older is a drinker. So since 168,219,590 people 18 
years or older drank in the past year, they are considered drinkers. Going 
by the stats (48.3% of US adults being male, & 51.69% female), that means 
77,885,670.17 men drink and 86,952,706.07 women drink at least once a 
year. So if 13% of the men drinkers (and 3% of women drinkers as mentioned) 
are binge drinkers then 10,125,137.1 adult men and 2,608,581.18 adult women 
are binge drinkers, or just short of 13 million American adults. 
12,733,718.28 is less than 4% of the population, and instead of being more 
than 1 in every ten Americans (like you thought), it is actually less than 
1 in 20 Americans.
comments.author: Drannon Moore

comments.text:
+Creationsofmyown

comments.text:

(thank you) but you, too, have misinterpreted them.  Upon further 
investigation, I have found that it is much worse than I originally 
thought.  The average drinker consumes 15 drinks per week.  When you take 
into account that this study includes those who drink at least once a YEAR, 
that is ridiculous.
comments.author: My real name is I AM

comments.text: +My real name is I AM  but apparently not how to read...
comments.author: Creationsofmyown

comments.text: +Creationsofmyown  I know how to do math.
comments.author: My real name is I AM

comments.text:
its percentage of drinkers, not population

go read the article it proves half the shit these clowns say is false
comments.author: Creationsofmyown

comments.text:
+Scott Morales  No.  You are misunderstanding the numbers.  It is closer to 
1 of 8 (7.7) drink EXESSIVELY plus the rest of drinkers.  If something can 
improve, it should.  I am (obviously) American so I am worried about the 
US, first.  We need to improve ourselves, then we can help the others.
comments.author: My real name is I AM

comments.text:
+My real name is I AM I'm not arguing over the merits of binge drinking or 
the consequences that follow. I'm just pointing out that if you want to get 
annoyed at anyone, America would be one of the last people you'd have a 
talking to. In fact, there are a lot of countries that should strive to 
reach America's standards of binge drinking. 

And please don't come back at me saying nobody should binge drink because 
obviously a percentage of them will drive drunk. Because low numbers should 
be praised, and high numbers should be scorned. You might personally think 
1 in 10 men drinking is unacceptable, but there's no arguing against the 
fact that comparatively, America is a country that's on the right side of 
the statistics.
comments.author: Scott Morales

comments.text:
No.  That's over 1 of 10 men taking in a 'dangerous' (unhealthy, to say 
the least) amount of alcohol 52 times a year.  Let's say 1 out of 10,000 
(low est.) of those men decide to drive.   That would be 2000 hazards on US 
roads EVERY WEEK.  It is likely 20,000 or higher (3000/day, just counting 
those in this study (6+ drinks)).

    When you factor in the health risks and possible manslaughter involved, 
that number is significant... No, it is APPALLING.
comments.author: My real name is I AM

comments.text: But that's a really low number in context. Do you understand that?
comments.author: Scott Morales

top_comment.text:
No offense intended but when it comes to drinking the americans are light 
weights. 6 drinks in one go isn't that much, not in Finland anyway.﻿
top_comment.author: omegavalerius

comments.text:
+Mike Orlando I have no idea what you base that assumption on. Drinks may 
be larger (as everything tends to be in the states) but I'm pretty sure 
that the 97,6% in industrial moonshine or 80% regular is right up there 
with any American moonshine.
comments.author: omegavalerius

comments.text:
+Mike Orlando no one drinks moonshine regularly though...but when you find 
good moonshine...
comments.author: GAndreC

comments.text:
American alcohol is a lot harder than most countries. It always has been. 
Moonshine and such.
comments.author: The Liberal Lion

comments.text:
+Martti Hänninen
 if you're used to drink or not also matters a lot, I think even more than 
weight, my great uncle (my grandpa's brother) was tall but scrawny, and 
once he managed to drink 5 litres of wine (and an whole cauldron of  soup 
with it) for lunch, and he got drunk twice a day until he died at 98.
comments.author: RZ-357

comments.text:
Sadly in Finland to some it is a thing of pride. But he is correct, that 6 
drinks is not much and i find it very hard to beileve, that a guy big as 
Cenk would get hammered drinking 6 shots/ drinks whatever.
comments.author: Martti Hänninen

comments.text:
It's regional, I drink 2-3 times a week and a minimum for me is probably 8 
if I have something to do the next day, but usually more than that and I'm 
a light drinker compared to most people I know. But since you mentioned 
Finland, most locals here are of Finnish or Scandinavian descent so maybe 
it's in our blood. In my home town, there are more bars on main street than 
all other businesses combined.
comments.author: Draco, King of Dragon Men

comments.text: "No offense"?  As if heavy drinking is something to be proud of.
comments.author: Amanda Tessmer

comments.text: not anywhere in Europe for that matter and i've been around...
comments.author: Angelo Ace

top_comment.text:
In Soviet Russia it is only considered binge drinking if it kills you, 
which is why so few votes were counted on their behalf.﻿
top_comment.author: FishDontBlinq

comments.text:
+vanteesomeone

LOL
comments.author: RoGoH308

comments.text: In Soviet Russia, alcohol drinks YOU.
comments.author: vanteesomeone

comments.text:
+Daniel Thomas

lol yes it does.
comments.author: RoGoH308

comments.text: Soviet Russia doesn't exist though.
comments.author: Ginger Lad

top_comment.text:
I'm male, born in Ireland, lived there for most of my life and I have never 
ever touched an alcoholic drink.........﻿
top_comment.author: RadioGaGaONE

comments.text:
+RadioGaGaONE Don't worry about it, mate. We all have our moments. The 
important thing is that you don't drink. Keep up the awesomeness!
comments.author: Sekhubara

comments.text: LOL I feel so dumb for letting that fly over my head.
comments.author: RadioGaGaONE

comments.text: +RadioGaGaONE A virgin also means someone who has never drunk alcohol.
comments.author: Sekhubara

comments.text:
Yeah I'm definitely a minority in Ireland XD That's part of the reason I 
moved to London. I didn't really fit in anywhere in Ireland. 
The reason I never touched alcohol is just because I don't like what people 
can turn into when they drink and have had first hand experience of it's 
effects from very early in my life. I don't look down at people who enjoy 
to drink and I have no real objection towards it as a whole it's just not 
for me. 
LOL What does virginity have to do with anything?
comments.author: RadioGaGaONE

comments.text: Staying sober is what Irish kids do when they wanna rebel
comments.author: Kemigon

comments.text: Still a virgin huh ?
comments.author: Cary Francis

comments.text: +Sekhubara You don't know what you are missing =)
comments.author: TheWhocares233

comments.text: +RadioGaGaONE Cheers to you for never touching alcohol.
comments.author: Sekhubara

comments.text: Why?
comments.author: Mattm1986

comments.text: I guess you are in the 44% then...
comments.author: ChiefWardo
